Name: Matthew Ajibade
Comment/Editorial: Nine deputies were fired from the sheriff's office in May amid internal investigations into Ajibade's death, and three others left the department earlier. Two have been indicted on related charges including falsification of logs and records. According to the autopsy report, Ajibade died from 'blunt force trauma ' a combination of abrasions, lacerations, skin injuries about the head and some other areas of the body.'

Name: William Jeffries
Comment/Editorial: The Counted said, 'Jeffries was reportedly intoxicated and urinating in public. When an officer arrived, he refused to take a breathalyzer test and leaned on a patrol car, according to police. The two entered into an altercation and Jeffries' head hit the car, breaking his neck. Jeffries died two weeks later in hospital.' To this, WVMetroNews only adds, 'Officer Eric Riddle was suspended pending an investigation, but was cleared by an internal investigation conducted by the Weston Police Department. He returned to work one week after the incident in question.'

Name: Joseph Hutcheson
Official_COD1: combined effects of cocaine and methamphetamine
Official_COD3: physiologic stress associated with struggle and restraint
Comment/Editorial: Rushed into Dallas County jail agitated and was subdued by Deputy; witnesses say aggressively. Hutchesons cause and manner of death was homicide with "combined effects of cocaine and methamphetamine, compounded by hypertensive cardiovascular disease and physiologic stress associated with struggle and restraint," according to the medical examiner's office.

Name: Christian Siqueiros
Comment/Editorial: In this case, there are very few facts to discuss, and The Counted's report is extremely straightforward: 'Squeiros died from a heart attack following a physical altercation with police, who were responding to a report that he was causing a disturbance. Police said he became combative and had to be restrained. Siqueiros's sister and a neighbour said that a large group of officers had been on top of him during the struggle.' NBC Los Angeles reports (and this is in the video, not the written story accompanying the video) that an unnamed witness, 'the neighbor who called authorities' who 'did not want to go on camera but said that Siqueiros was, 'acting strangely' and that his eyes were glazed over. Police ordered him to the ground and the man who called in the authorities said that the arest was orderly and not forceful.' NBC continues, 'Siqueiros allegedly 'became combative' when police arrived, and officers took him into custody, police said. While in custody, Siqueiros went into cardiac arrest and later died at the hospital, police said.'

Name: Andre Murphy Sr
Comment/Editorial: Officers responded to a motel to complaints of Murphy causing a disturbance, and had a range of physical interactions including an attempted but apparently failed TASER exposure and fighting (PKIC CONSIDERS THIS A DEPLOYMENT). Toxicology reports indicate there were high levels of methamphetamine in Murphy's system, which was within a range that most toxicologists would say would be toxic, police said. K-2 was also found in his system.

Name: Keaton Farris
Comment/Editorial: Inmate had flooded his cell so water was shut off; "systemic failures" led to missed welfare checks. Coroner stated dehydration was the cause of death. Sheriff's/coroner investigation report available

Name: Jonathan Sanders
Comment/Editorial: The Counted reports, 'An attorney for Sanders's family said an officer choked him to death with a flashlight. But police chiefs denied this, and said he sustained injuries during a physical fight involving no weapons. Sanders had been exercising his horse before the encounter with the officer, according to his family.' The Clarion-Ledger reported, "We don't know why he was going after Jonathan, we don't know what the reason for stopping him was, we don't know what led up to this incident,' Parish said, adding that he hasn't been able to talk to all the eyewitnesses yet. That's when an altercation occurred.  Details are sketchy by all accounts. Early reports had Herrington using a flashlight to strangle Sanders, but both Street and Parish have since said there was no flashlight. Parish said as far as he knows, Sanders did not have a weapon, but that Sanders ended up strangled to death.' The Associated Press later reported, 'Stonewall Police Chief Michael Street said he has turned the inquiry over to the Mississippi Bureau of Investigation, as is typical when a police officer is involved in someone's death in Mississippi. Warren Strain, the spokesman for MBI, said an autopsy has been completed and that Sanders' body has been returned to his family. He said MBI has notified the FBI, which he described as 'offering support.' Strain said autopsy results are being analyzed and he can't release a cause of death. Street and Mitchell said MBI is likely to hold a news conference in coming days to discuss the autopsy's findings. Strain described the encounter between Herrington and Sanders as a physical 'altercation."

Name: Jonathan Paul
Official_COD1: in-custody death with application of physical restraints
Comment/Editorial: erratic behavior

Name: Freddie Gray
Comment/Editorial: Suffered a single "high-energy injury" to his neck and spine; COD listed as "neck injury, homicide." to "unbelted occupant of a police transport van" six officers arrested and charged with second-degree assault, misconduct in office and reckless endangerment; three were charged with manslaughter, one with second-degree "depraved-heart" murder. Gray "tested positive for opiates and cannabinoid."

Name: David Munday
Comment/Editorial: Autopsy results not in as of Aug 25, service a sentence for shooting and officer back in 2002.

Name: Lorenzo Hayes
Street_address: N Addison St and E Sanson Ave
Comment/Editorial: reported to be drug dealer; meth, "brown liquid" and paraphernalia recovered.  Upon arrest appeared under the influence, evaluated on scene by EMS and taken into custody.    On scene excited delirium was observed by officers.  Excited delirium can often be fatal if prompt medical attention is not given.  Toxicology reports not released, individual went into cardiac arrest most likely related to narcotic induced excited delerium. ME claims COD as homicide and mechanism of death asphyxiation on vomit while being restrained in prone position along with cardiac arrest post-asphyxia

Name: Bruce Stafford
Comment/Editorial: The Counted states, 'Stafford was arrested for trying to sell stolen puppies. After arriving at the county jail for booking, a'brief physical altercation' occurred and Stafford became unconscious, according to police. He died after officers attempted to render medical assistance, according to police.' The Burlington Times-News reported that, '...there was a brief scuffle as 55-year-old Bruce Dean Stafford was being booked into the jail and Stafford collapseD....[J]ail staff as well as Hendersonville firefighters and the county EMS tried to revive Stafford. He was taken to Pardee Hospital where he was pronounced dead.' The Henderson Lightning reports, 'The officer 'was wearing a camera on his chest' that recorded all his interaction with Stafford. SBI agents have already interviewed Underwood and his supervisor, Simonds said, and the police department has turned over the camera footage to the state agency. Cameras in the jail also would have recorded the booking process.' Stealing puppies? Autopsy not released publically. http://www.blueridgenow.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20150713/ARTICLES/150719955/1022/section

Name: Joseph Slater
Comment/Editorial: Pepper sprayed entering a police car. Unclear if handcuffed at the time. After OC, decedent experienced a "medical emergency" Per http://www.highlandnews.net/news/breaking_news/article_712c2f76-e5e6-11e4-9921-777ce68d8709.html had a history of unsual disturbances.  Possible intoxication or underlying undiagnosed mental health issue?  No autopsy found.

Name: Denis Reyes
Comment/Editorial: family told responding officers he was under the influence of alcohol, synthetic marijuana and prescription medication, and that he was acting wildly and being uncooperative. http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/mentally-ill-man-dead-cops-respond-bronx-home-article-1.2291140 Individual had a history of violent episodes and was diagnosed schizophrenic and bipolar.  Autopsy report not available at this time and/or pending.

Name: Jermaine Benjamin
Comment/Editorial: ME report: "Benjamin died of excited delirium after taking Flakka"; 70 calls for service at this address; witnesses stated Benjamin was "tripping" http://www.wptv.com/news/region-indian-river-county/drug-related-death-investigated-in-indian-river-county Could be a mix of substance and mental illness, but is leaning more towards intoxification and/or excited delrium which is fatal if not treated.

Name: Troy Goode
Comment/Editorial: WHBQ Memphis reports that Goode, 'without explanation got out of the car and apparently started acting in an erratic fashion to attract the attention from a bystander, and they called Southaven Police.'€ Southaven Police say they believe Goode was on LSD. Police told FOX13 the 30-year-old was restrained and taken to Baptist DeSoto where he later died. Goode's attorney told FOX13 he has lots of questions about what happened between the time Goode left the scene and the time Goode's wife got the call two hours later. 'We know that he was hogtied and we know that he was placed face down on a stretcher, and we know a witness said he heard him say'I can't breathe.' We know he is an asthmatic and used an inhaler,' the police said. WHBQ continued by saying, 'We have also learned that the act of 'hogtieing' someone during arrest is used on a statewide level by law enforcement in Mississippi. It can be used by officers if a suspect could kick or otherwise injure an officer or EMT worker while being taken into custody.' News article suggests that Goode was under the influence of LSD which is a potent hallucinogen but statistically is not easy to overdose on.  Prelim ME report suggests Goode's COD was cardiac-related.

Name: David Dehmann
Comment/Editorial: Coroner Anahi Ortiz states  "Dehmann allegedly fell while incarcerated at the Knox County Jail" COD "traumatic brain injuries due to fall and was undetermined in nature."  Per http://www.10tv.com/content/stories/2015/04/29/mount-vernon-ohio-father-upset-after-son-dies-in-mount-vernon-police-custody.html Dehmann had Aspgerger's Syndrome, Tourette's Syndrome, and Autism.

Name: Samuel Harrell
Comment/Editorial: Prisoner; other inmates allege that Harrell was beaten by up to 20 officers and thrown down a flight of stairs; COD cardiac arrythmia.  Possible history of Bipolar Disorder

Name: Allen Hernandez
Agency: Tempe, Chandler and Mesa Police Departments [US Marshals Service Task Force]
Comment/Editorial: Preceded by car wreck and Hernandez entered a house, asked to use the phone and fought with three residents in the house. http://www.idahopress.com/members/death-of--year-old-homedale-man-under-investigation/article_61d3e832-1bc1-11e5-a95a-ef34b37e1d49.html Cause of death not released

Name: Jeffrey Jackson
Comment/Editorial: paranoid and pressumed schizophrenic, news sources elude to no error on the side of LE.  Individual went into respiratory arrest on scene.

Name: Mychael Lynch
Comment/Editorial: driving under the influence, no autopsy available

Name: Alvin Haynes
Official_COD3: heart disease and high blood pressure
Comment/Editorial: Haynes had an envelope in his hand that the deputies were trying to examine; when Haynes refused, the coroner says, "There was some type of interaction that led to some type of a confrontation with multiple deputies."

Name: Russell Sharrer
Comment/Editorial: An autopsy showed Sharrer had deadly levels of methamphetamine in his system. He also suffered from heart disease and emphysema. Had been pepper sprayed on admission to jail for non compliance

Name: Larry Kobuk
Comment/Editorial: stole cars, drove unsafe

Name: Filimoni Raiyawa
Comment/Editorial: Raiwaya, who was 6 feet tall and 265 pounds, was the caregiver to 96 year-old Solomon Cohen, who was badly beaten before 5 a.m. that day and was not expected to survive his head injuries. Raiyawa rear-ended a BMW, pushing it across the street and into parked car, according to the San Francisco Chronicle. The victim in the crash got out to talk to Raiyawa. The victim backed away, police said, and called 911 as Raiyawa got out of his car and approached him in a threatening manner, eventually chasing him around the block. When police responded, Raiyawa beat a female officer several times about the head and shoulders, beating her to the ground nearly unconscious, and throwing her partner by the wrist,' Suhr said. Willie Gunnari, 35, who lives on Lombard, said he saw the two female police officers trying to subdue the suspect. Gunnari said the man resisted, flailing his arms as the officers hit him with batons. 'Nothing was going to get him to stop moving,' Gunnari said. Witnesses reported that Raiyawa ignored repeated commands to get on the ground, and to stop resisting, and collapsed after he tried to break into a restaurant.  While waiting for EMS to come on scene individual went into respiratory arrest, CPR was performed with no successful outcome.

Name: Phillip White
Comment/Editorial: the report does not state how this situation began

Name: Thomas Allen Jr
Comment/Editorial: tried to ake off durin traffic stop

Name: Charly 'Africa' Keunang
Comment/Editorial: skid row homeless man

Name: Kevin Judson
Comment/Editorial: As Broyles arrived on the scene, he saw Judson fleeing, pulled his patrol car into a parking lot, parked it and gave chase on foot. Berry said during a foot chase the suspect ignored repeated commands to 'stop' and 'get on the ground.' The deputy fired his stun gun, but it failed to stop the suspect. According to Berry, the video shows the suspect getting into the deputy's patrol car. The two struggled for control of the car; the deputy drew his handgun and continued to order the man to give up. Berry said the suspect tried to put the car into gear. Witnesses said they heard the car's engine rev. During the struggle for the car, the suspect's hand was near the deputy's loaded AR-15-style rifle, which was mounted in the car, Berry said. The suspect then tried to drive off with the deputy's hand stuck in the door. Broyles then made the decision to open fire. The first shot hit Judson in the left arm and went into his chest. Broyles managed to free himself from the car as Judson put the car into reverse. Broyles' second shot hit the door jam. The car crashed into an electrical tower. Broyles fired two more times. One bullet hit the passenger's door. The other struck Judson in the head. Judson died at the scene. 'Deputy Broyles at the time he fired his weapon was reasonably in fear for his own life. He too, reasonably believed that to allow Judson to flee in the patrol vehicle, based on all that had transpired, could pose a significant threat to the community€'

Name: David Kassick
Comment/Editorial: Officer Lisa J. Mearkle stopped Kassick for o inspection sticker; Kassick fled and Mearkle TASED him and ordered him to show his hands; Kassick is said to have hidden one hand under his body and Mearkle shot him twice in the back. Mearkle was charged with criminal homicide after investigators concluded she shot Kassick twice on Feb. 2 without legal justification. Kassick had drugs and alcohol in his system and a syringe.

Name: Eric Harris
Comment/Editorial: Gun-sale sting in which Harris sold illegal gun to UC officers; Volunteer reserve officer shot Harris fatally; charged with manslaughter; Harris autopsy showed "acute intoxication by methamphetamine." Internal investigation into whether Bates' training records were intentionally falsified by Sheriff, to whom Bates had contributed money; Bates was not qualified by agency on .357 revolver used to shoot Harris; revolver was not on agency approved weapon list

Name: John Quintero
Official_COD1: two gunshot wounds, one to his 'upper medial left buttock' and the other in his 'lateral left buttock'
Official_COD3: Blunt force injuries to head, neck, back and extremities
Comment/Editorial: 911 received four calls stating the suspect was under the influence of alcohol and armed with a knife. Officers arrived and say Quintero was belligerent and confrontational. After being told to show his hands Quintero allegedly threatened officers.  Ordered to place hands on the SUV, Quintero refused, officers say. Officers TASED but innefective. Officer fired two rounds from .223 patrol rifle. POlice say Quintero allegedly 'was armed with a knife and began threatening to kill individuals in the residence.'and "allegedly put a knife to a 21-year-old woman's throat, and one witness told police he had assaulted his father with the knife before the two men went to the SUV." Two witnesses disgree and say Quintero's hands were up and he was not facing the officer who shot him. Autopsy sayd COD from two gunshot wounds, one to his 'upper medial left buttock' and the other in his 'lateral left buttock'. He suffered extensive internal injuries, underwent surgery and went into cardiopulmonary arrest and couldn't be revived, the autopsy report says. Quintero tested positive for alcohol, methamphetamine and marijuana, autopsy report also listed 'blunt force' injuries on his head, neck, back and extremities

Name: Joaquin Hernandez
Street_address: E Baseline Rd and S 48th St
Comment/Editorial: Hernandez had Salvador Muna, an armed felon sought by the USMS Fugitivee Task Force as a passenger in Hernandez' car; TF officers surrounded the car and ordered Muna to surrender but Muna leapt into the back seat, grabbed a gun and pointed it at officers, who opened fire, killing both Muna and Hernandez.

Name: Derek Cruice
Comment/Editorial: shot in face at door during search warrant, only marujuana found

Name: Walter Scott
Comment/Editorial: Officer claimed suspect ran,took taser & fought, video contradicts statement & shows officer shooting Scott in back; officer arrested and charged with murder

Name: Jeremy Lett
Comment/Editorial: Officer David Stith responded to a burglary call and encountered Lett on the 911 caller's front porch with his hand in his pocket; Stith approached Lett with his weapon drawn shouting, "Tallahassee Police! Show me your hands!" Lett yelled and tried to tackle Stith multiple times; Stith attempted to use his taser on Lett but it didn't work and even shocked Stith in the rain; Stith was tackled and pinned to the ground by Lett and that is when he fired his gun, killing Lett; ME says COD five gunshot wounds to the torso and left upper arm; Lett had cocaine in his system at TOD; Leon County grand jury found Stith was justified in his use of deadly force

Name: Sergio Navas
Street_address: N Pass Ave and W National Ave
Comment/Editorial: erratic driver

Name: John Deming Jr
Comment/Editorial: NBC Bay Area reports, 'Police said they found Deming just after 2 a.m. when responding to a burglary alarm at Specialty Sales Classics, a car dealership at 4321 First St. The Counted tells the story thusly: 'Police were responding to a burglar alarm when authorities said they encountered Deming inside a business acting'agitated and aggressive'. According to police, they attempted to use beanbag rounds to subdue Deming before he escaped through back window, where officer Daniel Kunkel began following him. Police say the two wound up in a physical altercation after Kunkel's Taser failed to stop Deming, who wound up on top of the officer,'pummeling his head'. Kunkel claimed he was afraid he would lose consciousness and fired his weapon once at Deming's torso and again at his face when the initial shot failed to stop the attack.' Apparently the crime involved malicious mischief: according to ABC7, 'Specialty Sales Classics salesman Jeremy Bolen says the hood of a 1967 Mustang was scrawled on with a sharpie. The suspect even walked on a Cadillac worth $115,000. 'You can't repaint this,' he explained. 'There's a bunch of other damage. Graffiti in the bathroom,' he added.' NBC Bay Area continues, 'Initially police said Deming was found in front of the business, but clarified Tuesday he was still inside but could be seen through the dealership's large front windows. Deming allegedly threw a 50-pound floor jack through the window, which landed on the sidewalk near the officers. Police fired at him with a beanbag round but missed, and Deming refused commands to leave the dealership, police said.' Deming then ran out the back through a broken window. NBC continues, '[Officer Daniel] Kunkel was standing watch in the back of the business and saw Deming jump through the broken window. Kunkel ordered him to stop but Deming kept running, and Kunkel hit him in the back with a Taser, according to police. The Taser didn't stop Deming, and Kunkel started to chase him until Deming turned and charged Kunkel aggressively, police said Deming allegedly kicked Kunkel in the stomach and punched him in the head, knocking him to the ground. Deming got on top of Kunkel, pummeling his head as he lay on the concrete, police said. Kunkel thought he might lose consciousness and used his Taser again, but again it had no effect, so he drew his pistol and shot Deming once in the torso. However, even that didn't stop Deming and he continued his attack, police said. Kunkel then fired two more rounds, hitting Deming at least once in the face, police said.'

Name: Johnny Ray Anderson
Comment/Editorial: Police were responding to reports of a prowler in the neighborhood but have provided little details on the the circumstances before Anderson's death. Anderson's wife said her husband had been fixing a bicycle near the house the homeless couple had been squatting in, but fled when police arrived due to a fear of being caught trespassing. Anderson jumped a fence and was then shot in the torso,' said The Counted. Details on this incident are unclear, and there is suspicion about why Anderson was shot. KTLA reported that, 'A 911 caller reported a man was knocking on his or her door and attempting to get inside the house, located in the 12200 block of 216th Street (map), around 9:40 p.m. Sunday.' NBC Los Angeles reported, 'The family said Johnny Ray Anderson was knocking on the home's door because he wanted to escape authorities, but authorities said on Sunday that deputies came after the report of a prowler.'

Name: Autumn Steele
Agency: Osage Nation Police Department, Osage County Sheriff's Office
Comment/Editorial: Steele and her husband, Gabriel Steele were in a domestic dispute and the officer was trying to break it up. Witnesses report that the dog attacked the officer suddenly and the officer fired, missed and killed Steele. The AP reported that the County Attorney said her decision not to charge the officer was supported by body camera evidence, witness statements and reports from the Iowa Division of Criminal Investigation. The officer had to make an instantaneous decision as the threat was occurring, Bevers said. The officer was treated for dog bite.

Name: Tony Robinson
Comment/Editorial: erratic behavior

Name: Naeschylus Vinzant
Comment/Editorial: parole violator, removed ankle bracelett

Name: Andrew Williams
Comment/Editorial: undercover drug deal, deseased tried to escape

Name: Jared Forsyth
Comment/Editorial: Range accident; Negligent discharge of weapon during training

Name: Brendon Glenn
Comment/Editorial: Chief Beck from LAPD: "Any time an unarmed person is shot by a Los Angeles police officer, it takes extraordinary circumstances to justify that, and I have not seen those extraordinary circumstances at this point." Autopsy COD multiple gunshots. Officer who shot Glenn was black.

Name: Christian Taylor
Comment/Editorial: Officer in training fired on Taylor.

Name: Artago Howard
Comment/Editorial: Police responded to an alarm at a pharmacy to find a burglary in process. A deputy arrived on the scene and found Howard inside the store. KNOE reports that a struggle ensued for control of the deputy's weapon, and it went off, shooting Howard. The deputy handcuffed Howard and upon noticing the injury called an ambulance.

Name: Michael McKillop
Comment/Editorial: Dragged officer along with car

Name: Sam Holmes
Comment/Editorial: traffic stop, tried to escape, dragged officer along with car

Name: Anthony Hill
Comment/Editorial: Police responding to a 911 call saw Hill hanging, naked, from a balcony and . Witnesses said that Mr. Hill, an African-American, approached the officer, who is white, with his hands either up or at his sides, but that he did not heed the policeman's order to  stop. Girlfriend described Hill as experiencing post-traumatic stress disorder and that Two weeks before the shooting, Hill stopped taking his psychiatric medication. Police say Hill lunged.

Name: Jeremy Linhart
Comment/Editorial: Warrant fugitive; gun in car; was attempting to get back into car when shot

Name: Ryan Bolinger
Street_address: Urbandale Ave and Merle Hay Rd
Comment/Editorial: Autopsy results not in as of Aug 25; no weapon recovered

Name: Jonathan Pierce
Street_address: Port St Joe Police Station, 410 Williams Ave
Comment/Editorial: According to FDLE investigation Pierce was arrested for theft and was being interrograted while unrestrained when he got hold of a firearm, likely that belonging to Sgt. William Garner, and shot himself. Garner had disabled his video body camera. FDLE states Pierce also had a razor blade secreted in his mouth at time of death. While FDLE says Garner acted unprofessionally, no charges filed

Name: Antonio Perez
Comment/Editorial: did not stop at traffic stop and fled in stolen car

Name: Salvado Ellswood
Agency: New York Department of Corrections and Community Supervision
Comment/Editorial: The Counted explains that, 'An officer said he fatally shot Ellswood after the man punched him in the face during an evening encounter behind a doctors' office building that he was patrolling. Police said the veteran officer, who had asked Ellswood to leave, first used his Taser but that it was ineffective.' This would appear to be relatively straightforward attack on a police officer. The officer reportedly attempted to end the assault on his person with a less-lethal solution_‹_the TASER_‹_and when that failed and the attack did not stop, the officer fired, killing the man. Plantation police Detective Philip Toman told media including Local10 that Ellswood, 'had an extensive arrest record, including acts of violence towards law enforcement officers. He also had an active warrant out for his arrest.'

Name: Salome Rodriguez Jr
Comment/Editorial: confrontation between rookie officer and deseased, officer fled to Mexico

Name: Asshams Manley
Street_address: Marlboro Pike and Walker Mill Rd
Comment/Editorial: Police state Manley had been expressing suicidal thoughts. "Despite being wounded, the man continued to fight with the officer and was not restrained until a second officer used a Taser on Manley multiple times, police said" - WaPo

Name: Frank 'Trey' Shephard III
Agency: Whitley County Sheriff's Department, Kentucky State Police
Comment/Editorial: "During the chase the suspect called 911 and was telling the dispatcher that he had a child in the car and that he would threaten to harm that child if officers attempted to pull him over or stop him," Shephard said to have reached back inside the vehicle after exiting it

Name: Kris Jackson
Comment/Editorial: Drug convictions and warrants; no weapon found

Name: John Unsworth
Comment/Editorial: TASED  multiple times but continued to approach officers

Name: Tamara Seidle
Comment/Editorial: Domestic/custody dispute between officer and his estranged wife; officer murdered wife in front of the couple's 7-year old daughter

Name: Michael Ireland
Comment/Editorial: Ireland fled police and was shot once in the back by officer. Ireland had been wanted in municipal (misdemeanor) warrants)

Name: Roberto Leon
Street_address: Elkhorn Blvd and Dry Creek Rd
Comment/Editorial: tried to escape traffic stop on motorcycle and drove away in stolen car, barricaded himself in house

Name: Albert Davis
Comment/Editorial: Davis was involved in a'very, very violent' struggle with an officer, according to police. The officer had been called after reports of a fight in the area involving five men. The officer deployed his Taser and then fired his gun once, striking Davis. Davis later died in hospital,' reports The Counted. The Orlando Sentinel gives this account : 'Orlando police were called to the apartment complex near the intersection of Curry Ford Road and South Conway Road after a fight broke out among five people, including Davis. When Vidro tried to arrest Davis, he took off running but was caught about 100 yards away. Instead of surrendering, Davis chose to fight with the officer, [Police Chief John] Mina said. 'Based on the physical evidence at the scene and radio transmissions, it appears there was a very, very violent struggle there,' Mina said. 'Our officer did use his Taser at some point during the struggle and a lot of his equipment, to include his Taser, baton, gun magazine, wristwatch and ball cap, were strewn about the scene of this violent struggle.' Mina said Vidro fired his gun one time, hitting Davis in the chest. Police attempted CPR until paramedics arrived. Davis was taken to a local hospital, where he was first listed in critical condition, then later died.'

Name: Darrius Stewart
Agency: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation
Comment/Editorial: The Counted reports that, 'Stewart was traveling in a vehicle that was stopped by police for a broken headlight. Authorities said he was placed in the back of a patrol car, unhandcuffed, while officers ran his name. When the officers returned to handcuff Stewart and take him into custody for outstanding warrants, police said he became combative and struck an officer with the handcuffs. The officer then drew his gun and fired. Stewart's mother told local news that her son had never been arrested and that the warrants were for someone else with the same name.' WMC Television reported that, 'Investigators said when the officer opened the back door to handcuff Stewart, he kicked the door and attacked the officer.' I note that if the account is correct and the officer was moving to handcuff Stewart, then the officer would presumably have received, or believed he had received, confirmation on the arrest warrants, which WMC states were for a sexual offense in Iowa and another offense in Illinois. WMC continues, 'During the fight, Stewart grabbed the officer's handcuffs and swung them at him. The officer grabbed his gun and shot Stewart to end the fight. Stewart went to Regional Medical Center in critical condition where he later died. The officer had several cuts and bruises from the fight, but he did not need to go to the hospital. He is relieved of duty pending the outcome of this investigation.' The Memphis Flyer identified the officer as 26-year-old Connor Schilling, and noted that 'Schilling, who worked in the MPD's Ridgeway precinct, had a previous suspension for a DUI arrest in Southaven in July 2014 , but criminal charges were dismissed in that case. He did, however, receive departmental charges after the incident. His personnel file also contains one excessive force case in 2013 that was found to be not sustained by the MPD.'

Name: Richard Jacquez
Comment/Editorial: Homicide warrant for his arrest; this incident disrupted a second homicide; this man was 2nd of three fugitives wanted for homicide and was in car with a woman police describe as a "next victim"; Police initially claimed Jacquez was "reaching for his wasitband" later retracted this statement and stated Jacquez was shit in the back fleeing from police

Name: Estevan Gomez
Comment/Editorial: The account by Officer Ray Tensing of the traffic stop was later disproved by body camera footage released by Cincinnati prosecutor Joseph Deters, who announced that murder charges were being filed against University of Cincinnati police officer Ray Tensing.' The Guardian later reported, 'Tensing had maintained he was 'dragged' by DuBose's vehicle after the two entered into a physical altercation and was forced to shoot, but Hamilton County prosecutor Joseph Deters said body-camera evidence completely contradicted this account. In a frank assessment of the officer's conduct, Deters said Tensing had 'purposely killed' DuBose and that he 'should never have been a police officer'' Fox News reports that 'Deters says the shooting of motorist Samuel DuBose in a 'chicken crap' stop over a missing front license plate was 'asinine,' and 'without question a murder.' He also said the university shouldn't be in the policing business at all. The prosecutor said he thinks now-fired Officer Ray Tensing lost his temper because DuBose wouldn't get out of the car'.

Name: Brandon Jones
Comment/Editorial: robbed conenient store

Name: Adam Jovicic
Comment/Editorial: deseased was ex boyfriend of officer, domstically violent

Name: Samuel DuBose
Comment/Editorial: Officer stated many facts that video disproved; charged with murder 1 and voluntary manslaughter

Name: Rub_n Garc'a Villalpando
Comment/Editorial: Garcia Villalpando had led police on a vehicle chase at speeds of up to 89 miles an hour; after stopping he got out of his car and approached the officer; was told at least 20 times to stop approaching before being killed; autopsy confirmed BAC of between 0.09 to 0.14

Name: Daniel Covarrubias
Comment/Editorial: "Covarrubias died from a gunshot wound to his head and had benzodiazepines and methamphetamine in his system at the time."

Name: Charles Hall
Comment/Editorial: Tried to drive away from officer during resisting arrest; Known to officer who killed him as being wanted for theft.

Name: Denzel Brown
Comment/Editorial: tried to steal at Best Buy, tried to carjack a car that had two small children in the back seat

Name: William Chapman II
Comment/Editorial: Coroner report showed no evidence of close range fire; witness reports seeing Chapman knock TASER from officer's hand, then lunge at officer. Officer indicted on 1st Degree murder charge; COD gunshots to face and chest, no drugs or alcohol

Name: Jose Herrera
Comment/Editorial: State prison incident; two inmates attacking a third who was on the ground. Correctional officer fired one warning shot to stop the attack, assailants continued to assault inmate; after warning officer fired, fatally woulding Herrera

Name: Demaris Turner
Comment/Editorial: Lauderhill police were investigating a stolen vehicle.  They confronted Demaris Turner in a stolen Hyundai Genesis; Turner rammed the car into a marked K-9 cruiser, which had an officer and a K-9 inside, deputies said. An officer fired into the car; Local10.com says that Turner was hit 11 times.

Name: Hector Morejon
Comment/Editorial: Police said the officer saw the man turn toward him, while bending his knees, and extending his arm out as if pointing an object which the officer perceived was a gun. The officer then fired; The apartment was spray-painted with gang-related graffiti; Morejon's family attorney rejected the gang allegation and ties; Since 2000 Long Beach has been the 72nd most deadly neighborhood out of L.A. County's 270 neighborhoods, according to a Times analysis of homicide data

Name: Joshua Dyer
Comment/Editorial: Passenger in a car that fled and then backed up towards officers

Name: Derek Wolfsteller
Comment/Editorial: A preliminary investigation determined that two people were trying to subdue the man when Therkelsen arrived. The man did not immediately submit to Therkelsen's demands, and she used her Taser on the suspect, which did not subdue him. When Therkelsen tried to physically subdue him, a fight ensued and the suspect tried to grab her gun from her holster. Therkelsen regained the weapon, and fatally shot the man.' The Minneapolis Star-Tribune reported after an interview with Wolfstetter's father, 'One day before the Plymouth incident, police were called to Wolfsteller's grandparents' home for a mental health crisis, but his father said Monday that police couldn't take him to the hospital against his will.' They add about the incident two important details: first, 'an Arby's employee [had] called 911 about a disturbance and, Duane Wolfsteller said, several restaurant employees tackled his son to the ground.' Second, 'The BCA said that, according to the preliminary investigation, officer Amy Therkelsen responded to a report of a disturbance, and was told on the way that the man had a weapon and was inside the restaurant. When she arrived, two people were attempting to subdue Wolfsteller. When he didn't immediately follow her commands, she used her Taser, but it proved ineffective, investigators said.' Plymouth Police Chief Michael Goldstein said€his department had had previous contact with Wolfsteller. He declined to elaborate.'

Name: Daniel Elrod
Comment/Editorial: Elrod was involved in a robbery of a Family Dollar in which he claimed to have a weapon; officers stopd Elrod's vehicle and ordered him to surrender & gave verbal commands to show his hands and to get on the ground. Elrod refused to comply with the commands, climbed on top of a parked car. TASER was ineffective and Elrod was shot.

Name: Alexander Long
Comment/Editorial: US Marshal's Service Task Force, Terre Haute PD sought Long for multiple rape and kidnapping charges; when attempting to ´box in the suspect vehicle with police vehicles' the suspect began ramming police vehicles; Long inserted his right hand inside of his ´heavy winter coat' at which point he was TASED ineffectively; as he withdrew his hand he was shot by police. Judged justified.

Name: Glenn Lewis
Comment/Editorial: Lewis was driving a vehicle that refused to stop when ordered by police, then turned and drove toward officers, who fired at the vehicle. When it stopped officers saw Lews had been shot, fatally wounded.

Name: David Felix
Comment/Editorial: Itinerant man with few recent family ties; history of mental illness and frequent run-ins with the law; attacked officer with radio during investigation; Both cops were taken to the hospital with injuries to their heads

Name: Spencer McCain
Comment/Editorial: officers responded to 911 calls for the address 17 times since 2012

Name: Jessica Hernandez
Comment/Editorial: Hernandez, 17, was driving a stolen car with four teenaged passengers to flee from officers when she attempted to strike with the car an officer trying to stop her. That officer fired, killing her; witnesses disputed the officers' statement however the district attorney notes the coroner states, "The locations of the bullet strikes from Officer Jordan's gunshots are consistent with his description of being extremely close to the car, pushing off of the car with his left hand, and shooting at the driver with a downward trajectory as the Honda was moving forward, with the gun in his right hand." Ruled justified.

Name: Joshua Garcia
Comment/Editorial: tried to escape in police car

Name: Billy Patrick
Comment/Editorial: Patrick had a felony warrant for parole violation; as the officer attempted to take him into custody, Patrick tried to hold the officer's head underwater; officer emerged and shot Patrick

Name: Dean Genova
Comment/Editorial: Officers responded at about 4 a.m. to the pharmacy, found front door smashed and Genova inside standing on a ladder. Genova fought with officers as they tried to subdue him, and he bit one officer's arm and snatched another's handgun

Name: Ernesto Javier Canepa Diaz
Comment/Editorial: Ernesto Canepa was sitting in a vehicle that matched that of a man who had robbed a gold chain from a woman earlier. Police have not released details but a replica BB gun was found in the vehicle

Name: Feras Morad
Comment/Editorial: under the influence of magic mushrooms, young student

Name: Deven Guilford
Comment/Editorial: Sgt. Jonathan Frost stopped Guilford after Guilford flashed his brights at Frost's vehicle to (erroneously) warn Frost that his brights were on. Frost effectEd stop on PC that Guilford used brights within 500 ft. Guilford argued he did nothing and refused to produce license and insurance. the argument continued as Guilford got out of the car and Frost went to arrest, Guilford resisted. Frost TASED Guilford but did not get good contact; the two grappled and rolled into a ditch; Frost said Guilford was stop him and punching him when Frost fired several times. DA ruled this justified after reviewing video and statements

Name: Allan White
Comment/Editorial: White was waiting outside the home of a female deputy, 'allegedly hiding behind a vehicle' when she returned to her home in the middle of the night. White, 'ran out towards her and attacked. The sheriff said Oakley attempted to subdue White with a Taser before shooting him.' According to WCRB TV, White 'tackled her and they got in a scuffle and he took his hands and put them around her face and tried to kill her,' Sheriff Eric Watson said. The deputy attempted to TASE White, which was unsuccessful in stopping the attack, before resorting to deadly force by shooting him. Sheriff Watson added, 'He was clearly on her property and close to her front door.'

Name: Felix Kumi
Comment/Editorial: Kumi was caught in crossfire as police fired at suspects in an undercover gun buying operation.

Name: Ralph Willis
Comment/Editorial: was murder suspect

Name: Fridoon Rawshannehad
Comment/Editorial: Officer stated Rawshan was armed with a knife; this turned out to be a metallic pen. Rawshan had been diagnosed with schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, the courts found him to be mentally competent to stand trial on at least two criminal cases; his mother on April 28 filed documents for a restraining order against; "Respondent is bipolar and can become aggressive and violent," she wrote.

Name: Garrett Gagne
Comment/Editorial: Officer responding to an alarm at a business at around 4 a.m. when he struck Gagne who was lying in the road on a darkened stretch. No autopsy released as of June 2015

Name: Jeffrey Surnow
Comment/Editorial: deseased eas riding his bicycle

Name: Michael Kocher Jr
Comment/Editorial: Michael Kocher Jr. was struck by a Toyota, whose driver called police, Officer Irvin Magayanes responded and on arriving at the scene, hit Kocher with his patrol vehicle, and Kocher died at the scene. Magayanes was charged with second-degree negligent homicide

Name: Shawn Watashe
Comment/Editorial: homeless struck by cop car

Name: Donald Pinkerton-DeVito
Comment/Editorial: Accident; unclear if bike hit car or vice versa

Name: Neil Van De Putte
Street_address: Lacey Rd and Deerhead Lake Dr
Comment/Editorial: The Counted notes that, 'While crossing a street, Van De Putte was struck by a police patrol car being driven by an officer who was responding to an unrelated call. Authorities said Van De Putte was walking against the traffic signal.' This is another horrible accident that seems to be added to this database for the purposes of inflating the numbers. But in this case, it is so obviously biased against the officer that it neglects even in its brief description to mention that it was 3:40 am at the time of the accident, and it mischaracterizes as 'authorities said' a witness report stating that Mr. van de Putte was crossing against the signal, and neglects entirely to mention that the officer tried to avoid Mr. van de Putte to the extent that he crashed his patrol car into a utility pole. The Asbury Park Press reported, 'Lacey Police Officer Andrew Slota was responding to a call and traveling East on Lacey Road when his patrol car struck Vandeputt before veering off the road and into a utility pole following an evasive maneuver by the officer. Witnesses to the incident indicated that Vandeputt was crossing against the traffic signal to the north of Lacey Road at the Deerhead Lake intersection when he was struck by Slotta, [Ocean County Prosecutor's Office spokesman Al] Della Fave said. According to Della Fave, though Slota attempted to avoid Vandeputt, the pedestrian was struck by the front passenger side of the patrol vehicle, and after impact the vehicle struck a utility pole on the westbound side of the road, eventually coming to rest in the bank parking lot adjacent to the roadway. Vandeputt was pronounced dead at the scene by Dr. Konomos from Newark Beth Israel at 3:47 a.m. Slota was taken to Community Medical Center where he was treated for non-life threatening injuries.'

Name: Bernard Moore
Comment/Editorial: officer was apparently speeding, not on a call, no lights or sirens and struck deseased

Name: Jason Champion
Comment/Editorial: walked away from broken down car, got struck by police car

Name: Nuwnah Laroche
Comment/Editorial: walked away from broken down car, got struck by police car

Name: Dean Bucheit
Comment/Editorial: LAPD officer struck pedestrian who was walking in the road.

Name: Hue Dang
Street_address: Jackson Ave and E Kennedy St
Comment/Editorial: seems to be accident, officer turned corner and hit woman

Name: Alan Dunnagan
Comment/Editorial: officer struck civilian car, reported to have failed to stop at intersection

Name: Alan Williams
Comment/Editorial: Coroner's Office ruled Crouch's death accidental; family questions investigation after finding Crouch's personal property at accident site two days later

Name: James Payne Jr
Comment/Editorial: Special prosecutor appointed; officer resigned july 16

Name: Nyal Brown
Comment/Editorial: The Counted says, 'Brown was turning on to a main street, driving a van. He was killed after being struck by an SUV being driven at high speed by a sheriff's deputy. Authorities said the deputy was pursuing a separate suspected drunk-driver who had just narrowly avoided crashing into the SUV before speeding away.' While this accounts notes the high speed, I can't help but note that it does not include the undisputed fact that the deputy had his lights and sirens on. Witnesses state this was a horrible accident. The Columbus Dispatch reports, 'Bud Brown's van was pulling out from a KeyBank parking lot on the south side of Sullivant just west of Demorest Road when it was struck on the driver's side by the eastbound deputy's SUV, said Columbus Police Sgt. Brooke Wilson of the accident-investigation unit.' WBNS TV elaborates, 'He exited in front of the cruiser and turned in front of the cruiser. The cruiser struck the driver's side of the van,' said Columbus Police Sgt. Brooke Wilson. 'The van actually rotated 360 degrees across the street and came to rest where you see it now. During the rotation of the van, the driver was ejected.'€ 'Obviously our thoughts and prayers are with this individual,' added Franklin Couty Chief Deputy Jim Gilbert. 'This is somebody's father. This is somebody's family member. And obviously our concerns are with that family.'

Name: Louis Becker
Street_address: New York State Rte 23 and Cairo Junction Rd
Comment/Editorial: Becker, 87, was killed in a traffic accident when he pulled his vehicle into the path of a New York state trooper's SUV on State Route 23.

Name: Howard Robbins
Comment/Editorial: Robbins was hit while walking by a patrol car. The officer performed CPR but Robbins was pronounced dead at the scene.

Name: David Watford
Comment/Editorial: officer was looking for truck driver who abandoned truck and struck truck driver

Name: James Moore
Comment/Editorial: pedestrian hit by police car

Name: James Bush
Comment/Editorial: The St. Clair Shores police officer was eastbound on Eight Mile approaching Intestate 94 when he saw a vehicle pass in the opposite direction with no headlights on, state police Lt. Calvin Hart told MLive Detroit. The officer made a U-turn and began heading west. While following the vehicle in preparation to make a traffic stop, the other vehicle turned left off Eight Mile into a driveway and the officer followed, at which point Bush crashed into the front-passenger side of the police car.' Police Chief Todd Woodcox told the Macomb Daily, 'We cannot undo the tragedy, but we can promise a full and complete investigation into the circumstances surrounding the crash'

Name: Barbara Ramey
Comment/Editorial: cop car was chasing another vehicle, wife got struck in her car

Name: Thomas Ramey
Comment/Editorial: struck by cop car

Name: Wendell Hall
Comment/Editorial: According to initial reports, a southbound Honda Civic driven by a 37-year-old woman made a left turn into the path of a northbound police department Ford Explorer, which hit the Civic in the front passenger door. Alcohol found in car, driver admits drinking

Name: Bryan Overstreet
Comment/Editorial: Struck by police car; police state Overstreet was lying in road; family disputes

Name: William McIntire
Street_address: N 40th St and E Flora St
Comment/Editorial: It is unclear whether McIntire was killed by the vehicle; video shows him staggering before the vehicle arrived, and he had a history os passing out drunk in the road

Name: Darrell 'Hubbard' Gatewood
Official_COD1: cocaine-related toxicity coupled with police action
Comment/Editorial: Autopsy states cardiac arrhythmia due to cocaine-related toxicity coupled with police action. Gatewood's probable manner of death is undetermined, the report states. Thyroid disorder and pulmonary emphysema are listed in the report as other significant medical conditions.

Name: Donald 'Dontay' Ivy
Comment/Editorial: Family described him as a paranoid schizophrenic they said suffered from heart problems; autopsy shows deceased had taken his anti-psychotic medication; officers were on anti-gun patrol; officers asked if decedent had every "been in trouble" and decedent replied no, computer check showed domestic dispute 8 years previous. City DA requested Governor appoint NYAG to investigate citing appearance of conflict;

Name: David Lynch
Comment/Editorial: Autopsy (see links) shows acute intoxication, methamphetamine, amphetamine, and multiple blunt impact injuries; hypertensive cardiovascular disease,  COD: asphyxia due to physical restraint

Name: William Dick III
Comment/Editorial: Dick had robbed allegedly at gunpoint (no weapon found) a man for $150 and fishing equipment, then led police on a vehicle and then foot pursuit. Okanogan County Coroner Dave Rodriguez Ruled out the Taser as cause of death, ruled out asphyxia, trauma, heart attack or heart condition.

Name: Wilber Castillo-Gongora
Agency: Owyhee County Sheriff's Office, Homedale Police Department, Owyhee County Posse
Comment/Editorial: Castillo-Gongora called the sheriff's office to report he had run out of gas, then again to report a disturbance. Deputies and DPS troopers say the man was upset and behaving erratically and running into the traffic lanes; deputies tased him once and then again when he continued to refuse to follow instructions, he died at the hospital

Name: Brian Pickett
Comment/Editorial: Pickett's mother called LAPD to report her son was under the influence of drugs and threatening her life; officers arrived and described Picket as agressive; he was TASED and cuffed. When paramedics arrived to remove TASER darts he became unresponsive and died.

Name: Tony Ross
Comment/Editorial: autopsy ruled homicide, deseased was on meth

Name: Shane Gormley
Comment/Editorial: Mr Gormley was killed by the Utah State patrol when he suffered a heart attack after being TASED four times. As The Counted tells it, 'Gormley suffered a heart attack after being shocked with a Taser four times during a struggle with a trooper, according to authorities. After eluding capture by police several times in the preceding few days, following his escape from a jail work-release scheme, he beat an elderly woman and attempted to steal her car in an effort to escape from the trooper. He was placed into a coma in hospital but died a week later.' The important thing to note here is that officers attempted to protect Mr Gormley using less-lethal force despite the circumstances of his chase and subsequent arrest. And this is a great example of how context is important_‹_as horrible as that Counted account makes Gormley sound, reality is much, much worse. Mr. Gormley had in fact been, as The Counted says, on work-release from jail (where he was serving time on a retail theft conviction); the 30 year old had escaped, then after stealing a motorcyle and getting stopped by the state police on a traffic charge, Gormley used the motorcycle to escape again. Gormley then stole a car from Wasatch Front Kia. According to FOX13, police, 'went to the apartment where Gormley's girlfriend lives near 24th St. and D Ave. in Ogden. They saw him jump from the apartment window and speed off in her car. Troopers chased Gormley to 21st St., where they boxed him in but he ran from the car and tried to carjack others. Authorities said he tried to carjack a truck and trailer but didn't get in.' Then, according to KSL.com, 'Investigators looking for Gormley found him Monday. He attempted to escape by jumping into a car driven by a 53-year-old woman. He punched, scratched and bit the woman in an attempt to get her out of the car, according to the UHP. Troopers used Tasers on Gormley four times before taking him into custody. After he was handcuffed, shackled and taken out of the car, Gormley went into cardiac arrest, according to the UHP. Gormley was taken to McKay-Dee Hospital Center where he was placed in a medically induced coma.' He later died. KSL continues, 'Tests showed [Gormley] was under the influence of methamphetamine and opiates at the time.' FOX13 reports that the medically induced coma was necessary precisely because of the amount of methamphetamine in Gormley's system.

Name: Troy Robinson
Comment/Editorial: Ran from officer on traffic stop, fell from 8' wall

Name: Matthew Russo
Agency: Los Angeles County Sheriffs Department, Baldwin Park Police Department
Comment/Editorial: Russo weighed in excess of 400 lbs

Name: Natasha McKenna
Street_address: Fairfax County Adult Detention Center, 10520 Judicial Dr
Official_COD1: excited delirium associated with physical restraint
Comment/Editorial: Was in restraints at the time of being TASED 4 times in county jail after non compliance with order to bend knees; history of schitzophrenia; Autopsy states COD "excited delirium associated with physical restraint, including the use of conducted energy device;" the term 'excited delirium' is medically controversial

Name: Michael Lemon
Comment/Editorial: Said to have fought police as they attempted to arrest him for disturbance; deputies used batons, OC spray and TASER

Name: Ross Anthony

Name: Terrance Moxley
Comment/Editorial: reported to have bad reaction to something

Name: Michael Gallagher
Comment/Editorial: disscovered during break in

Name: George Mann
Comment/Editorial: According to the [Georgia Bureau of Investigation], officers responded around 4:15 a.m. on July 11 to a call reporting an individual acting 'crazy' in the caller's garage at 5100 Rock Place Drive in unincorporated Stone Mountain. The caller said 'his male neighbor was locked in his garage, was irate and possibly armed.'' The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported that, 'Officers made contact with the man and 'an altercation ensued,' Doan said. 'The suspect went unresponsive at the scene and was transported to Eastside Medical Center where he was pronounced dead,' Doan said.' The Georgia Bureau of Investigation told the Gwinnett Daily Post that, 'Mann was stunned with the taser when he resisted the officers and went unresponsive at the scene. He was transported to Eastside Medical Center where he was pronounced dead.' Neither The Counted nor the AJC mentioned, but the GBI did note, that 'a gun and suspected methamphetamine were found in the garage where Mann was [arrested]' according to the Daily Post.

Name: DaJuan Graham
Comment/Editorial: reported to act irratic

Name: Chance Thompson
Comment/Editorial: Officers were called by security when Thompson was running around climbing and posing in karate positions. "Acute ethanol and methamphetamine intoxication ...COD hypoxic encephalopathy die to cardiopulminary arrest after a violent struggle."

Name: David Werblow
Comment/Editorial: pressumed to have schizophrenic episode

Name: Oscar Ruiz
Comment/Editorial: suspect had stolen a large American flag and flag pole from a gas station and had been swinging it at cars and people in the area

Name: Sheldon Haleck
Comment/Editorial: erratic behavior

Name: Darrell Brown
Comment/Editorial: Repeatedly kicked at door, behind which a mother and four female children hid, until the door broke. Was chased out by the mother and neighbors until police arrived.

Name: David Kapuscinski
Comment/Editorial: Girlfriend reports Kapuscinsky 'awoke from a nightmare and began beating her; child of girlfriend called police; Wayne County Medical Examiner's Office listed Kapuscinski's cause of death as cardiac dysrhythmia, an irregular heartbeat

Name: Askari Roberts
Comment/Editorial: family called police, paranoid, crazy behavior

Name: Norman Cooper
Comment/Editorial: "APD officials said officers were forced to deploy their Tasers, but Cooper removed the probes shot from the device." Prior conviction of assault family violence

Name: Kevin Bajoie
Comment/Editorial: TASED  multiple times but continued to approach officers

Name: Terry Price
Comment/Editorial: A casino from which Price was barred called police to remove him; Smith led cops on a vehicle chase, then a foot chase, then fought with police who TASED and Price collapsed. Autopsy COD 'sudden cardiac death associated with physical restraint in prone position with hands cuffed behind back, multiple electroshock weapon discharge,' noting there was PCP in his system at the TOD.

Name: Steven Davenport
Comment/Editorial: Lauderdale County Coroner Clayton Cobler said Davenport suffered scratches and bruises but suffered no life-threatening injuries. Cobler said Davenport had a heart disease and that it is possible that his heart gave out during the struggle and that drugs may have also been a contributing factor

Name: U
Comment/Editorial: 911 caller reported man was "on drugs"

Name: Calvon Reid
Comment/Editorial: Reid was in a retirement home covered with cuts and blood with torn clothing and was reportedly incoherent and aggressive with medical personnel; officers arrived TASED multiple times; Autopsy confirmed TASER contributed to death and that Reid tested positive for cocaine and alcohol

Name: Randall Torrence
Comment/Editorial: acted irratically in parking lot

Name: Billy Collins
Comment/Editorial: had heart surgery two weeks prior

Name: Wilmer Delgado-Soba
Comment/Editorial: Delgado-Soba died after he was shocked with a Taser 'after allegedly charging at police in a grocery store. Officers had been called when Delgado-Soba entered the store shirtless and began knocking items of shelves, according to police, who stressed that he was given several verbal warnings.' The Worcester Telegram reports that Delgado-Soba had entered the store and begun smashing glass and throwing things. The store owner, Mike Maranda, said 'police 'tried everything' before using the Taser.'€ 'Mrs. Maranda said the officers did not strike the man in any way. 'They tried very hard to talk to him,' she said, noting the man had resisted them by swinging his arms and hands.' The Telegram, which links to the police scanner recording, notes that dispatchers told the responding officers, 'He's destroying the store, and he's got a couple bottles in his hands.' Mr Delgado-Soba had convictions for, among other things, assault with a dangerous weapon, breaking and entering in the daytime with intent to commit a felony, assault and battery and intimidation of a witness

Name: Richard Davis

Name: Roberto Ornelas
Agency: Scottsdale Police Department, Phoenix Police Department
Comment/Editorial: Roberto Ornelas succumbed to "delayed complications of acute drug toxicity," the Miami-Dade County Medical Examiner Department wrote in a report. Investigators are not sure what kind of drug Ornelas took. It is listed on the report as an "unknown substance." Officers arrived when Roberto was destroying his room and his father called police. Father and police say he was incoherent, erratic and speaking in tongues, with blood on the walls of his room.

Name: John Kaafi
Comment/Editorial: Traffic stop turns violent witness say cops beat kaafi drugs found in car, extensive violent history

Name: Markus Clark
Comment/Editorial: Reported by witnesses to be high on Flakka, family admits flakka use, Clark's temperature at the hospital was 106.3 degrees Fahrenheit before he died.
